Definitions.Definition_Content: For a group $G$ and a subset $X \subset G$, the subgroup $H$ generated by $X$ is defined as the intersection of all subgroups of $G$ containing $X$. It is the unique smallest subgroup of $G$ containing $X$ and consists of all elements of the form $x_{1}^{\varepsilon_{1}} \cdot \ldots \cdot x_{n}^{\varepsilon_{n}}$ where $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in X$ and $\varepsilon_{1}, \ldots, $\varepsilon_{n} \in \{1,-1\}$, with $n$ varying over $\mathbb{N}$.
A group $G$ is called cyclic if it is generated by a single element. This is equivalent to the existence of a surjective group homomorphism $\mathbb{Z} \longrightarrow G$.
The order of a group $G$, denoted as ord $G$, is defined as the number of elements in $G$ if $G$ is finite. If $G$ is infinite, its order is said to be infinite.
The order of an element $a$ in a group $G$ is defined as the order of the cyclic group generated by $a$ in $G$. It is the smallest positive integer $m$ such that $a^{m}=1$.

Theorems.Theorem_Content: Let $x$ be an element of a group $G$. Then the subgroup $\langle x\rangle \subset G$ generated by $x$ in $G$ consists of all powers $x^{n}, n \in \mathbb{Z}$. This subgroup coincides with the image of the group homomorphism $\mathbb{Z} \longrightarrow G, n \longmapsto x^{n}$, where $\mathbb{Z}$ is the additive group of all integers. In particular, $\langle x\rangle$ is commutative.

Let $G$ be a cyclic group. Then $G \simeq \begin{cases}\mathbb{Z}, & \text { if } \text { ord } G=\infty \\ \mathbb{Z} / m \mathbb{Z}, & \text { if } \text { ord } G=m<\infty\end{cases}$. In particular, the groups $\mathbb{Z}$ and $\mathbb{Z} / m \mathbb{Z}$ for integers $m>0$ are the only cyclic groups, up to isomorphism.
Let $H \subset \mathbb{Z}$ be a subgroup. Then there exists an integer $m \in \mathbb{Z}$ such that $H=m \mathbb{Z}$. In particular, every subgroup of $\mathbb{Z}$ is cyclic.

(i) Every subgroup $H$ of a cyclic group $G$ is itself cyclic.\n\n(ii) If $\varphi: G \longrightarrow G^{\prime}$ is a group homomorphism, where $G$ is cyclic, then $\operatorname{ker} \varphi$ and $\operatorname{im} \varphi$ are cyclic.
Let $G$ be a finite group, $a \in G$. Then ord $a$ divides ord $G$ and we have $a^{\text {ord } G}=1$.

Let $G$ be a finite group such that $p:=\operatorname{ord} G$ is prime. Then $G$ is cyclic, $G \simeq \mathbb{Z} / p \mathbb{Z}$, and every element $a \in G, a \neq 1$, is of order $p$. In particular, every such element a generates $G$.
